intro: Abutilon newberryi, commonly known as the desert hibiscus, is a shrub native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its hairy, glandular stems and broad, heart-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces showy, five-petaled flowers in shades of yellow, orange, and red, which bloom in late summer to early fall. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, preferring well-drained soils and full sun exposure. Abutilon newberryi is drought-tolerant and often used in xeriscaping due to its low water requirements and ornamental value.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abutilon newberryi is primarily native to the southwestern United States and northwestern Mexico. It is commonly associated with areas that have a Mediterranean climate, characterized by hot, dry summers and mild, wet winters. Abutilon newberryi is well adapted to arid conditions and is often seen along canyon walls and in washes.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abutilon newberryi was mainly introduced to the western United States, particularly in California and Nevada.
